verses.text: At this, my heart trembles and leaps out of its place.
verses.comment: Elihu begins by expressing awe at God's grandeur; note the recurring biblical motif of trembling before divine majesty (see Ps. 119:120).

verses.text: Listen closely to the thunder of his voice and the rumbling that comes from his mouth.
verses.comment: Thunder is used as a symbol of God's power and presence, echoing themes found in Psalm 29.

verses.text: He unleashes it under the whole sky, and his lightning to the ends of the earth.
verses.comment: God’s sovereignty is universal, His actions touch the whole world (see Ps. 97:4).

verses.text: After his voice roars, he thunders with a majestic sound; though his voice is heard, he holds nothing back.
verses.comment: God’s voice is both powerful and unrestrained, connecting to imagery of creation reacting to God’s command (Ps. 104:7).

verses.text: God thunders wondrously with his voice; he does great things that we cannot comprehend.
verses.comment: Human limitation in understanding God’s works reflects themes found in Romans 11:33, inviting humility before mystery.

verses.text: For he says to the snow, ‘Fall on the earth,’ and to the rain shower, ‘Be strong.’
verses.comment: God controls nature directly, which hints at divine governance and providence found throughout Scripture.

verses.text: He seals up the hand of every man, so that all may know his work.
verses.comment: Sealing hands signifies God restricting human activity, revealing dependence on the Creator.

verses.text: Then the beasts go into their dens and remain in their hideouts.
verses.comment: Nature responds to God’s seasonal rhythms; a visible sign of His order.

verses.text: Out of its chamber comes the whirlwind, and cold from the scattering winds.
verses.comment: Whirlwinds often symbolize divine intervention or judgment.

verses.text: By the breath of God ice is given, and the broad waters are frozen.
verses.comment: God’s spirit or breath governs nature, recalling the creative activity of the Spirit (Genesis 1:2).

verses.text: He loads the clouds with moisture; he scatters his lightning through them.
verses.comment: Rain and lightning display God’s power over creation, emphasizing his ongoing involvement.

verses.text: They turn around by his guidance, to accomplish all he commands, over the face of the whole earth.
verses.comment: God’s sovereignty is total; no part of creation is outside His will.

verses.text: Whether for correction, or for his land, or for mercy, he causes it to happen.
verses.comment: Nature serves God's purposes, including discipline and mercy; hints at the Lord's gracious providence.

verses.text: Hear this, Job; stop and consider the wondrous works of God.
verses.comment: Elihu invites reflection on God's deeds; see Psalms’ invitation to contemplation.

verses.text: Do you know how God commands them and makes the lightning shine from his clouds?
verses.comment: A rhetorical question underscoring limited human understanding before divine mystery.

verses.text: Do you understand the balancing of the clouds, the wondrous works of him who is perfect in knowledge?
verses.comment: This verse highlights God’s infinite wisdom and perfection, themes repeated in Psalm 139.

verses.text: You whose garments become hot, when the earth is still because of the south wind?
verses.comment: The imagery points to human experience in facing God’s wonders, contrasting knowledge with simple observation.

verses.text: Can you, like him, spread out the skies, hard as a cast metal mirror?
verses.comment: The reference to the heavens as a molten mirror emphasizes divine craftsmanship, prefiguring language about God as Creator.

verses.text: Teach us what we should say to him; we cannot prepare our case because of the darkness.
verses.comment: Acknowledgement of God’s transcendence and human inability to speak rightly before Him; echoes Job’s earlier complaints.

verses.text: Should he be told I want to speak? Or should someone wish to be swallowed up?
verses.comment: The fear of speaking before God underscores reverence; see Job’s response later in 40:4-5.

verses.text: Now, people cannot look at the bright light in the sky after the wind has passed and cleared them.
verses.comment: Light imagery here subtly foreshadows themes of divine glory, which find fulfillment in the New Testament revelation.

verses.text: Out of the north comes golden splendor; around God is awesome majesty.
verses.comment: The motif of God’s brightness and majesty anticipates scriptural depictions of theophany.

verses.text: The Almighty—we cannot find him; he is great in power, in justice and abundant righteousness, and he does not oppress.
verses.comment: Affirms God’s attributes: power, justice, and mercy—qualities ascribed to the divine throughout scripture.

verses.text: Therefore, people fear him; he shows no favor to any who are wise in their own heart.
verses.comment: Divine wisdom is linked to humility and reverence (see Job 28:28 and Ps. 111:10). Spiritually, this prepares for themes of obedience and submission to divine revelation, which in Christian tradition point to the necessity of surrender and trust in the fullness of divine authority. High Christology: echo of fear and awe that surrounds Christ’s divine majesty and wisdom (Matt. 7:28-29).
